title: How to Plan Meals for Diabetics

steps.headline: Consider meals you love to eat.
steps.description:
Dieting with diabetes does not have to be a damper on enjoying delicious food. If you find that certain meals raise post-meal blood glucose more aggressively, find subtle ways to modify those recipes without sacrificing flavor. For example:
Replace difficult ingredients, such as pasta and white rice, with heartier ingredients that have a lower glycemic index, such as spaghetti squash, pasta made from chickpeas or edamame, and brown rice.

steps.headline: Understand glycemic index (GI) and glycemic load.
steps.description: Generally, choose a balanced array of ingredients—some of which have a higher GI and some of which have a higher glycemic load. This helps prevent hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia that results from an inconsistent release of glucose into the bloodstream during digestion. Glycemic index is a numerical score (0-100) that indicates how rapidly a food will make your blood glucose level rise. Foods containing simple carbohydrates, such as fruits, fruit juices, and sodas, have a GI closer to 100, while foods higher in fiber and/or fats, such as non-starchy vegetables, cheese, and whole milk fat yogurt have a lower GI. Glycemic load, unlike GI, measures the overall effect a food has on blood glucose level—how far blood glucose will rise after eating. Glycemic load is calculated by dividing the GI by 100, then multiplying that quotient by the number of grams of carbohydrates in a typical serving of the ingredient in question. For example, watermelon has a GI of ~80 but a glycemic load of only ~5 . To balance the glycemic impact of eating watermelon, pair it with a healthy fat source, such as olive oil and feta cheese. Garnish the mixture with mint leaves, and you have a delicious salad to pair with grilled chicken or fish.

steps.headline: Avoid heavily processed ingredients containing refined grains and added sugars.
steps.description: White breads, sodas, fruit juice cocktails, and even pre-made smoothies are full of simple carbohydrates that spike blood glucose severely and metabolize quickly, lending to the risk of hypoglycemia later in the insulin duration, or action period. Bear in mind that different types of the same product may impact blood glucose drastically differently. For example, making oatmeal from a canister of unsweetened rolled oats provides a sustained release of carbohydrates into the bloodstream, while a flavored microwaveable packet of oatmeal likely contains added sugars that may elevate blood glucose more rapidly.

steps.headline: Read the “Nutrition Facts” label on packages.
steps.description: What is the listed serving size? How many grams of carbohydrates are in each serving? Is there high-fat content or high-fiber content that might lower the glycemic index? Is there added sugar that could lead to a spike in blood glucose? Food manufacturers are legally obligated to provide this information, so look closely for it!

steps.headline: Calculate the total number of grams of carbohydrates in the entire batch of food.
steps.description:
For example, if a recipe for broccoli, cheese, and rice casserole calls for 3 cups of steamed white rice (about 1 cup of dry rice) and 12 oz. of frozen broccoli, calculate the total as follows:
Determine the total amount of carbohydrate in 1 cup of dry white rice. According to the Nutrition Facts label, the serving size is ¼ cup, which contains 36 g of carbohydrates. Therefore, the amount of carbohydrate in 1 cup of dry rice (3 cups steamed) is equal to 36*4 g, or 144 g.
Determine the amount of carbohydrates in 12 oz. of frozen broccoli. Assuming you must use the entire bag, simply multiply the “Total Carbohydrate” amount listed in the Nutrition Facts by the number of servings in the container. Sum the carbohydrates for each ingredient together to obtain the total for the recipe. In this recipe, only the rice and broccoli contribute carbohydrates; the cheeses and seasonings used are classified as non-carbohydrates and do not need to be taken into account when calculating carbohydrate content.

steps.headline: Use measuring cups and kitchen scales to measure ingredients precisely.
steps.description: If you do not have access to those tools, estimate. According to the National Diabetes Education Program, a fist equals about 1 cup, a palm equals about 3 oz., and a thumb equals about 1 oz.

steps.headline: Determine the number of carb choices you or your loved one needs per day.
steps.description: A carb choice is equivalent to 15 grams of carbohydrates. Examples of a carb choice include 1 slice of bread, ¾ cup of blueberries, and about 1½ cups of steamed broccoli. According to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, carbohydrates should account for 45 to 65 percent of an individual’s total daily calories. To illustrate, if your CDE or HCP recommends a 2,000 calorie/day diet, you should consume between 225 and 325 grams of carbohydrates each day.

steps.headline: Refer to the carbohydrate total for the recipe when deciding how much of a food to eat.
steps.description: Fractioning the total to calculate the carbohydrate amount on your plate is an easy way to ensure you or your loved one takes the proper amount of insulin with a meal. If you cannot easily measure out a portion, estimate using the approximation tools listed in Method 2, Step 3.

steps.headline: Build your plate of food based on the recommendations of your CDE or HCP.
steps.description: The National Diabetes Education Program recommends that about half of each plate should consist of non-starchy vegetables, while the other half of each plate should contain one protein choice and one starch choice .

steps.headline: Try to make meal sizes consistent.
steps.description: If one meal tends to be bigger than others, talk to your HCP or CDE about adjusting your carbohydrate-to-insulin ratio during that time of day.

steps.headline: Do not go more than 4-5 hours without eating.
steps.description: This is a standard clinical recommendation for diabetics that is aimed at preventing low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), which can be deadly if undetected or left untreated.

steps.headline: Choose snacks that contain a balance of carbs, fat, and protein.
steps.description: These satiating foods will carry you or your loved one through to the next meal and help keep blood glucose in range by minimizing the risk of severe blood sugar spikes and simultaneously preventing excess bolus or basal insulin from causing hypoglycemia.

steps.headline: Always carry fast-acting carbs with you to treat hypoglycemia, should it occur.
steps.description: If your or your loved one’s blood glucose is below 70 mg/dL but still higher than 55 mg/dL, consume 15 grams of carbohydrates, such as a juice box, an applesauce pouch, or four glucose tablets. Double this amount if the blood glucose is below 55 mg/dL. Be sure to check your blood glucose level again 15 minutes after consuming fast-acting carbs, and repeat the above protocol if the blood glucose level is still low.

steps.headline: Eat a small snack with protein, such as a handful of nuts, before bed if your blood sugar typically drops overnight.
steps.description: Depending on the recommendations of your HCP or CDE, you may reduce or forego a bolus altogether.

steps.headline: Time your insulin dosing carefully.
steps.description: If you use an insulin pump, try using its “extended bolus” feature when you eat foods that have a low GI and a high glycemic load, such as pizza. You can also set a high temporary basal insulin rate on most insulin pumps to compensate for any additional carbohydrates you plan on consuming over the span of a few hours.

steps.headline: Use calorie counting apps or look for nutrition information on restaurants’ websites when eating at chain restaurants.
steps.description: Most chains publish nutrition facts on all their menu items. If you are eating at a local restaurant that does not publish nutrition information, either ask about the ingredients and portion sizing of your dish or wait until the dish arrives at your table to estimate carbohydrate amounts.

steps.headline: Never take insulin immediately after ordering your meal.
steps.description: If your meal is delayed, you risk developing severe hypoglycemia.

steps.headline: When in doubt, ask for information about your or your loved one’s meal.
steps.description: If you are in a pinch and do not have time to seek out such information, order food that you know how to bolus for.

steps.headline: Understand that although there is so much to consider in meal planning for diabetics, mastering one or more of the above methods is a meaningful step toward ensuring long-term health with diabetes.
steps.description: Always consult your HCP to see which methods are best for you and remember that no one is perfect at managing diabetes. Mistakes are a part of the learning process; nevertheless, self-education will help you reduce the frequency of these errors.

Examples of a carb choice include 1 slice of bread, ¾ cup of blueberries, and about 1½ cups of steamed broccoli. Fractioning the total to calculate the carbohydrate amount on your plate is an easy way to ensure you or your loved one takes the proper amount of insulin with a meal. The National Diabetes Education Program recommends that about half of each plate should consist of non-starchy vegetables, while the other half of each plate should contain one protein choice and one starch choice . Timing Meals and Snacks Do not go more than 4-5 hours without eating. This is a standard clinical recommendation for diabetics that is aimed at preventing low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), which can be deadly if undetected or left untreated. Choose snacks that contain a balance of carbs, fat, and protein. These satiating foods will carry you or your loved one through to the next meal and help keep blood glucose in range by minimizing the risk of severe blood sugar spikes and simultaneously preventing excess bolus or basal insulin from causing hypoglycemia. If your or your loved one’s blood glucose is below 70 mg/dL but still higher than 55 mg/dL, consume 15 grams of carbohydrates, such as a juice box, an applesauce pouch, or four glucose tablets. Double this amount if the blood glucose is below 55 mg/dL. Depending on the recommendations of your HCP or CDE, you may reduce or forego a bolus altogether. Time your insulin dosing carefully. If you use an insulin pump, try using its “extended bolus” feature when you eat foods that have a low GI and a high glycemic load, such as pizza. You can also set a high temporary basal insulin rate on most insulin pumps to compensate for any additional carbohydrates you plan on consuming over the span of a few hours. Eating out With Diabetes Use calorie counting apps or look for nutrition information on restaurants’ websites when eating at chain restaurants. Most chains publish nutrition facts on all their menu items. If you are eating at a local restaurant that does not publish nutrition information, either ask about the ingredients and portion sizing of your dish or wait until the dish arrives at your table to estimate carbohydrate amounts. Never take insulin immediately after ordering your meal. If your meal is delayed, you risk developing severe hypoglycemia. When in doubt, ask for information about your or your loved one’s meal. If you are in a pinch and do not have time to seek out such information, order food that you know how to bolus for. Always consult your HCP to see which methods are best for you and remember that no one is perfect at managing diabetes. Mistakes are a part of the learning process; nevertheless, self-education will help you reduce the frequency of these errors.
